awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Irving Dai "Combinatorial Aspects of Floer Theory and Applications to Homology Cobordism." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Tomasz Mrowka.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Department of Mathematics

por.por_cntn:
During the tenure of this project, the PI developed tools and techniques for investigating the shape of abstract structures in three and four dimensions. The study of these objects has formed a major area of research in mathematics, which has both drawn from and contributed to advances in theoretical physics. More broadly, ideas from the field of topology and geometry have influenced the language of data analysis, biology, and artificial intelligence. As part of this project, the PI introduced new methods for studying and analyzing questions involving knots, surfaces, and manifolds in three and four dimensions.

In collaboration with other mathematicians, the PI was able to develop and use these techniques to settle open questions in low-dimensional topology, provide new computations of invariants, and exhibit novel examples of interesting topological phenomena. In addition, the PI was also able to establish interesting connections between topological techniques and ideas from other areas of mathematics, such as algebraic geometry. The PI hopes to continue this exchange of research ideas between different communities of mathematicians.

As part of the project, the PI also served as a mathematical mentor for numerous younger researchers. Such activities included supervising suitable research projects for high school students, running individualized reading courses for undergraduates interested in mathematics, and helping organize various conferences bringing together graduate students and other researchers in low-dimensional topology.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/07/2023
Modified by: Irving Dai
